Do we reserve some query parameters or do we hard code `blocking`=true and `result`=true? 
If we hardcode blocking=true and result=true then all query parameters for the GET are user defined, and they could potentially have parameters in their action named `blocking` and `result`
A get based activation should by definition be blocking and only the result returned - otherwise I don't see the point of adding this feature.
We are still seeing this test failure.

With respect to consistency, the policy we select may also affect how the RESTification configuration is handled.  After an action is RESTified and the swagger configuration sent to the API Gateway, what is the behavior when the action is deleted?

Personally, I prefer the "Don't allow" behavior with sufficient messaging to indicate why the delete cannot occur, and perhaps hints/instructions on how to remove the constraint.

@perryibm regarding the tmpfs=memory problem we could make the storage in /tmp also configurable similar to action limits for memory. so the user could decide to have 
- 0MB - "true" read-only (i.e. no /tmp storage)
- 32MB
- 64MB
- 128MB

etc.

This would then simply be added to the overall size calculation for container density.

Thoughts?

After reading through some points raised by @lehoanganh in other issues, @rabbah and I think the cleanest way to do this is with a default set of limits and a per deployment set of limits.  These are 2 different sets of variables and WhiskConfig will export the more specific one so we have the option of choosing whatever we want for any deployment but still have a default in case it is unspecified.

For the CI configuration, we will deliberately set lower limits so the throttle tests will work.  It also makes sense since the CI cluster is deliberately tiny.  For large deployments, we will use higher limits (higher than what we currently have) so that users are not impacted.

@psuter and I agreed to collapse the ArtifactStore and AttachmentStore abstraction as part of this pull request. That this interface will work for other stores (e.g., relational) is already questionable as there are Couch details that permeate once you set aside the put/get/del methods.

@csantanapr pointed out that for a web browser GET, it would be nice to project a particular field from the result object and interpret it as HTML.

Here's a proposal:

1)  a GET on https://user:pw@ip/api/v2/ns/package/action/invoke returns the JSON object as text.
2) a GET on https://.../invoke/foo projects the foo field of the JSON object, and returns it as text.
3) a GET on https://../invoke/html projects the 'html' field of the JSON object, and returns it as HTML.

Case 3) involves magic -- we build in a convention that if a field is named 'html', then when we project it during a blocking call via GET, we return it as type HTML.    

We can add other conventions for other standard types, like images.

With this proposal, a GET on the html field of the following method will just work.

main() { return { "html" : "<html>Hello</html>" }
- [ ] Implement this proposal (if accepted)

Hi @skaegi,
yes, currently that's Bluemix specific code and you're right, that the auto-binding behaviour is not yet documented.

For this issue respectively the only "workaround" is to use an Org/Space combination in Bluemix where there are no `_` present in either organization or space name.

**Auto binding in a nutshell:**
Check the [script to install the weather package](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/catalog/installWeather.sh#L15). It provides a parameter `bluemixServiceName` which is the service_name used in CloudFoundry (`weatherinsights`) in this case.
That value is actually the `label` attribute of said service in CloudFoundry, which can be obtained using the [CF Services API](https://apidocs.cloudfoundry.org/241/services/list_all_services.html) against Bluemix. In this case, call `GET https://api.ng.bluemix.net/v2/services` and search for the service you need.

I hope that clarifies things a little bit, if not let us know!

^^ I would state that in the design each namespace does have a name and id (uuid) field. 
This is because we need a human-readable version of the namespace for UI + CLI.
The CF integration service then just happens to use ORG_SPACE as a display name and spaceGuid as id. 

On question 2. Internally we should operate only with the uid of the namespace. The display name can be lazily updated whenever we do synchronize with the backend on the actual namespace list.
This of course makes the assumption that a space guid does not change when the space name changes.

I think we pretty much agreed on the first part (as shown in the JSON examples above, the fields are considered to be there).

The second part though will be a semantic change, as we currently always operate with the human-readable way. Also note that we still do not have a central notion of a "namespace" as in: Update one record to update the display name. That might become necessary, maybe it doesn't .

Technically we need a two way lookup:
1. **uuid** to **namespace**: To be able to authenticate the user
2. **namespace human-readable-name** to **namespace**: To be able to resolve human-readable-name to uuid to be able to fetch entities (given they are prefixed with uuid instead of human-readable-name)

The latter is problematic currently (maybe not, read below), because there are **N** subject entries resolving **namespace human-readable-name** to **namespace**. We could potentially use only the entry of the current subject (making it **(human-readable-name, subject)** to **uuid**) which kinda defeats that problem. But then we strike eventual-consistency because the current subject record might not have been updated with the information from CF (see the update mechanism outlined above).

After all, having **N** entries resolving **namespace human-readable-name** to **namespace** might actually be not too problematic as that would _only_ induce, that we have a timeframe where two different names are resolved to the same uuid (this timeframe is the time it takes to update every single occurrence of the old name in the system to the new name in the system) which might be indefinite. Again this could be completely irrelevant as the records with the "old" name are unused anyway (as stated by the update mechanism outlined above) hence we could ignore/accept this fact.

Having written this down, it appeals to me that "simply" having a view from **namespace human-readable-name** to **namespace** is sufficient as it it embraces the eventual-consistency introduced by the lazy update mechanism anyway. It states, that the renamed namespace will become available in OpenWhisk as soon as the **first** subject record is updated in our database which strikes me as more useful than to introduce that inconsistency for each subject record on its own.

My proposal would then be:
1. Use `namespaceUuid/actionName` internally, but the human-readable versions on the API side, resolve those internally using a view from **human-readable name** to **namespace** (thus **uuid**).
2. Renaming as stated by @domdom82 only affects the display name and should be handled as an update rather than a delete/recreate. The space guid does not change on a rename.

I was trying for this in my free time, but now I'm scared because I think it's a schema change -- it appears we'll have to store QualfiedNames in Rule entities, and I'm scared to do schema changes by myself.

Assigning to @rabbah since he's mentioned this was "easy".

It is not a schema change per-se. This can be solved incrementally.

As you noted, we'll need to store fully-qualified names instead of "just" the entity name. We'll also need to be able to disambiguate "old" entries (with just the entity name) and "new" entries (with the FQN).

Chances are, this detection is today a simple `name.contains("/")`.

@bjustin-ibm, changed to NAMESPACE or NAME.

@rabbah There is one additional item that is not directly related to sequences, but it is useful to have before implementing sequences:
1. Refactor code to include method for package resolution (i.e., fully resolved the actual package that a binding refers to) and method for generating all entities that need to be checked during entitlement check (this is also related to bindings and recursive bindings). 

A couple of other details that have been mentioned somewhere else:
1. The logs of the sequence activation record will contain the activation ids of the actions that ran. 
2. The annotations of the sequence activation record will contain a field "kind" with the value "sequence" for an easy way of figuring out which activations come from sequences. 

We also need to decide on how we count sequences toward DoS limits, e.g., do we count the sequence execution as +1 or +N where N is the number of actions that run as a result of invoking a sequence.
